III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12703 Policy and procedure
Section • (1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
Description procedures for the adoption services provided under R
400.12704 to R 400.12713
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency has failed to complete needed paperwork for an adoption
of an out of state child since October 2024. A contract was sent to
the agency in October of 2024 and has not yet been signed. The
agency originally agreed to sign this out-of-state contract and after
5 months it is still not complete. The agency will not return
communication.
Investigation Potential Adoptive Parent 1 was contacted via email on 3/11/25,
requesting a telephone number to discuss the allegations.
Potential Adoptive Parent 1 was interviewed on 3/12/25 and
3/26/25 via telephone. On 3/12/25, Potential Adoptive Parent 1
reported the same information as the allegation and had no
additional information to add. On 3/26/25, Potential Adoptive
Parent 1 was interviewed again and reported now receiving
information from the agency different from the team and had no
additional information to add. He was satisfied with the process
and updated information of the adoption and Chief Administrator
and Michigan’s Adoption and Program Guardianship Program
Analyst had explained why the process was taking longer than the
first adoption process.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed on several
occasions via email and telephone. During the interview that
occurred on 3/12/24, Chief Administrator explained this was a
complicated adoption case from Texas with many components
and individuals involved in the process. He explained Potential
Adoptive Parent 1reached out to their Adoption Specialist on
11/4/24 and discussed with her that his family wanted to complete
an adoption with their agency from the state of Texas with a child
who had special needs. CA reported Potential Adoptive Parent 1
was familiar with their agency and this Adoption Specialist as the
Potential Adoptive Parent 1 had gone through successful adoption
with the agency in 2022. CA reported his agency wanted to be a
good steward and since the agency had already completed a
difficult adoption for this family with special needs, and from
2

another state, they agreed to do the adoption. Ennis Adoption
Specialist requested the Texas agency submit their requirements
for the private adoption and a contact person name and/or other
credentials. CA reported once Adoption Specialist received this
information, she shared it with CA.
CA reported when he reviewed the adoption information
requirements and noted how much confidential information was
needed from Ennis, he had an administrative team meeting with
the administrators from Ennis. CA reported he and the
administrators decided on 11/6/24 that the agency would not take
the adoption case or complete the adoption process for this case.
CA reported he informed the Texas agency, Our Community Our
Kids (OCOK) and the Potential Adoptive Parent 1of the agency
decision on 11/6/24.
CA reported the next day on 11/7/24, Ennis received an email
from OCOK requesting a reconsideration. CA reported he
suggested having a meeting with OCOK, their adoption team and
Ennis administrators to discuss the Texas requirements. CA
reported after the meeting, he requested the documents from
OCOK that needed to be reviewed by Ennis and signed to begin
the preliminary process of adoption. He reported that Ennis
received OCOK documents on 11/11/24 that needed to be signed
to start the adoption process along with additional requirements.
CA reported on 12/3/24, Ennis had a Teams Meeting with OCOK
to discuss the documents they were requesting from Ennis. He
reported prior to this meeting; Ennis was under the understanding
it was only a home assessment that was required. However,
during this meeting the CA was advised that Ennis would also be
completing a home assessment of Potential Adoptive Parent 1
and Potential Adoptive Parent 2’s home and Ennis would also be
doing case management when the adoption case is assigned.
CA reported he contacted OCOK after the meeting and advised
them that Ennis could work with this agency to get this adoption
completed. CA reported that all documents that were previously
sent to Ennis were completed and sent back to the Texas agency
handling the adoption. All required paperwork at that time was
returned to Texas on 3/10/2025. However, on 3/28/2025 OCOK
requested twelve more documents that needed to be completed.
On 4/3/2025 Ennis sent all of the requested documents to OCOK.
Note: CA assigned himself to this adoption case due to the
number of documents that needed to be completed. He reported
3

Adoption Specialist was no longer working with Potential Adoptive
Parents case. It is also noted that the child for adoption was not
assigned to Ennis due to all needed documents and assessments
that needed to be signed and completed prior to the agency
assignment. CA reported the paperwork from Ennis to Texas went
back and forth during the next several months and on 3-10-2025,
Ennis was advised there was a subcontractor consent that needed
to be signed by the Executive Director of Ennis. He reported this
document was signed and sent back to the representative of
Texas handling the adoption on 4/3/2025.
Quality Improvement and Contracts Specialist of Texas was
interviewed via telephone on 3/12/2025. She reported this
adoption is a process, and their agency works multiple contracts
at a time as well as actively reviewing existing contracts. She
reported regarding the timeline for completing this adoption
process is not a matter of Ennis or OCOK, not actively working on
this adoption process. She reported that both Ennis and OCOK
took the appropriate time to make sure what was needed and
came together to review the required documents and have been
turning in the paperwork requested timely to OCOK and her
department to Texas. The Quality Improvement and Contracts
Specialist reported she has been going through those items as her
active schedule allows and as the adoption process is near the
end. She reported she was working to make sure Potential
Adoptive Parent 1 and Potential Adoptive Parent 2’s notifications
were active so they could be added to the network and hopefully
notifying them would help in understanding the process better.
She reported this timeline is not abnormal by any means and the
contracting process can take from 30-60 days.
Documentation reviewed:
• Ennis – Williamston generic caregiver notification adoption
policy was reviewed. It states that when a child is placed in a
foster/adoptive home with the provider’s name, the social service
caseworker or agency case manager will acquire the signatures
from each foster parent to acknowledge receipt of the K-908-2279
and Attachment A; and will also acquire these signatures when
there is an update to Attachment A.
• Ennis uses the Adoption Contract policy Adoption Code,
1974 PA 296, (MCL 710.let seq) also known as the Michigan
Adoption Code. The policy states that Children are available for
adoption following the termination of parental rights or following
the voluntary release of parental rights with commitment to
MDHHS. All foster youth available for adoption, with adoption as
their permanency goal, must be referred for adoption services.
4

• The following dates and contact information were observed
in casework notes from Ennis to Potential Adoptive Parent 1:
It was observed that Potential Adoptive Parent 1 was on every
email. It is also noted that the Team were comprised of Ennis
administration, Potential Adoptive Parent 1 and Potential Adoptive
Parent 2, Michigan Adoption and Guardianship Analyst, Michigan
Interstate Compact of Placement of Children, Texas Quality
Improvement and Contract Specialist, and Texas agency, Our
Community Our Kids (OCOK) representee:
• 12-03-24, Potential Adoptive Parent 1 as well as the entire
Texas Team were advised Ennis would enter the contract
for the adoption case.
• 12-06-25 Email sent to Texas requesting a date as to when
they would like the documents. Potential Adoptive Parent 1
was on this email.
• 01-02-2025 Email received from Potential Adoptive Parent
1 requesting an update on documents for Texas.
• 01-03-2025 Email sent to the Team including Potential
Adoptive Parent 1 advising everyone it was Ennis intention
to send all of the documents at the end of the week of 01-
09-2025.
• 02/10/2025 Email received from the Potential Adoptive
Parent 1 requesting an update due to a family vacation. On
2/10/2025 OCOK as well as Ennis responded advising the
Potential Adoptive Parent 1 to take their family vacation.
• 03/11/2025 Email sent to the Team with the Potential
Adoptive Parent 1 attached advising everyone there was
another document from OCOK that needed to be
completed from Ennis.
• 03/13/2025 Email sent to the team with Potential Adoptive
Parent 1 advising everyone there were documents that
needed to be edited due to policies of OCOK.
• 03-17-2025 Email sent to the Potential Adoptive Parent 1
requesting their phone number. The reason for the phone
call was an update on the progress as well as to advise
them Ennis believes OCOK has everything they need to
move forward with the adoption.
• 03-25-2025 The team was advised there was another
document that needed to be edited at the request of
OCOK.
• 03/27/2025 The team was advised a help desk ticket was
called in due to problems with the portal Texas uses.
• On 03-28-25 OCOK requested 12 more documents.
• On 04-03-2025 Ennis sent all of the requested documents
to OCOK.
5

• 04-09-25 The Team was advised ICPC was received, and
that the prior Ennis assigned Adoption Specialist was no
longer with the agency.
• 05-09-2025 The team was advised the child has not been
added to MISACWIS as of this date
Analysis Based on an enormous number of documents, emails, and active
communication among the adoption team that was observed and
included the Potential Adoptive Parent 1 and Potential Adoptive
Parent 2, it is not substantiated that Ennis did not comply with the
signing of the contract to work with the OCOK agency and that the
Potential Adoptive Parent 1 and Potential Adoptive Parent 2 were
not well informed of the communication and progress that existed
among the team regarding their Texas adoption. Ennis has an
adoption policy in place for adoption of youth who have a
permanency goal of adoption and followed their policy.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
